ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Knowledge on statistical mechanics and electromagnetism.
For statistical mechanics, we continued our discussion on thermodynamics and focused on microscopic picture of entropy and ideal gas law. 
For electromagnetism, we went through electrostatics and magnetostatics, and then discussed cases of changing fields.
I got a little bit of understanding about a smattering of physics topics. Somewhat like Phys 180/181 where it overs a lot so it's hard to get much from each unit.
Further adventures in Physics problem-solving. Thorough understanding of statistical mechanics and advanced electrodynamics.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strength: The lectures are well-organized, and Professor Padmanabhan explains the ideas in a clear way.
Weakness: I think the discussion on electromagnetism is a bit more complicated than other parts, so maybe we should spend more time on this topic.

Support is good, weekly office hours are pretty necessary. The class moves really fast which I know can't be changed as there are a set amount of topics to cover, but It seems like we moved on before I was ever able to understand the previous topic. A small annoyance, but section is hard to focus through as it's a bit long (75-85 mins), maybe add a 5 min break in the middle?

This was a good course. The workload was pretty manageable, and Professor P challenged us while not throwing anything at us we couldn't handle. The only weakness I'd say is sometimes I felt like emphasis was put on pure problem-solving rather than understanding the material conceptually.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The design of combination of recorded lectures and live virtual discussion sections.
Recorded lecture was nice as long as it got uploaded Sunday afternoon, any later and it was a struggle to get it watched before section

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes I would recommend this course to those who are comfortable with calculus and differential equations. I think the difficulty of this class is fair as an advanced level physics class.
This is a class for Physics majors, I'm not sure why you would want to take it unless you have to for the major.
Yes! I think it pretty well prepared me for more advanced Physics classes to come.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Recorded lecture and live virtual discussion section
Recorded Lecture and live virtual sections and office hours
